description: bust portrait of Christ as a child with light wavy hair, with a high hairline, with head turned slightly toward PR; Christ squeezes a bunch of grapes in his PR hand, with the juice running into a white footed bowl; Christ holds a small bunch of grapes in his PL hand, which are reflected in the silver cross-topped domed cover in foreground; small portions of view of a landscapes in top corners; portrait in a tondo, with flowers in each corner
medium: Linen warp, wool, silk and gilt weft yarns
text: The Infant Christ is characteristic of tapestries produced in the Southern Netherlands around 1500, which were small in size (typically less than six feet square) and dealt with Christian iconography, especially themes related to Christ’s crucifixion. This tapestry depicts the infant Christ pressing grapes into a chalice, a reference to the physical sacrifice he would later make for humanity, and which would be celebrated in the Eucharist. It is exceptional for its costly materials and refined techniques of manufacture. When compared to extant tapestries in museum collections, this example stands out as superior for its focused subject matter and streamlined design.
title: The Infant Christ Pressing the Wine of the Eucharist
